tn.ref: the anger of Yahweh was ignited against Israel
tn.text: The word "ignite" means start a fire. Here Yahweh's anger is compared to that of a fire. AT: "the anger of Yahweh started to burn like a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"he caused David to oppose them"
In the law of Moses, God prohibited the kings of Israel from taking a census of fighting men. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This phrase uses two place names Dan, in the far north, and Beersheba, in the far south, to represent the entire country. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: count all the people ... fit for battle
tn.text: This means to count all the men except those men who are either too young, too old, or physically unable to fight.
This means "produce 100 more people for every one person there is now." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: the king's word was final against Joab
tn.text: Joab and the other commanders of King David's army were not able to convince David to not take a census.
This phrase represents the king's command to them. AT: "what the king had commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"Joab and the commanders of the army crossed"
This was a city on the northern edge of the Arnon River. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a town in Gad. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This may refer to the town of Kadesh in the land of the Hittite people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Joab and the commanders had gone"
"9 months and 20 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Then Joab reported the total of the count of the fighting men to the king
tn.text: "Then Joab told the king the total number of men ready for battle"
This refers to the northern tribes of Israel.
"eight hundred thousand ... five hundred thousand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This metonym refers to the men who were ready to fight in the army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the southern tribe of Judah.
The "heart" here is a metonym for David's emotions and conscience. AT: "David felt guilty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Now, Yahweh, take away your servant's guilt
tn.text: David refers to himself as "your servant." This is a polite way to speak to someone with greater authority.
This is an idiom that means Yahweh spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:07:03|7:3]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "word" represents Yahweh's message. AT: "the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means Gad was the official prophet in the royal palace.
"I am in terrible trouble"

tn.ref: Let us fall into Yahweh's hands rather than into the hand of man
tn.text: Here "hands" refer to power or control. AT: "Let Yahweh and not people punish us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the time God decided he would stop the plague.
"70,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Here mentioning the city of Dan in the extreme north and the city Beersheba in the extreme south means the entire nation of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: the angel reached out with his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it
tn.text: Here the metonym "hand" stands for the angel's power. AT: "the angel was about to destroy the people in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Yahweh changed his mind because of the harm
tn.text: This means that Yahweh stopped the evil that he was allowing the angel to do. AT: "Yahweh felt grieved about the harm"
The metonym "hand" stands for the angel's power. AT: "Do not harm them any longer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
A threshing floor was a hard, flat surface where edible grain was separated from chaff.

tn.ref: I have sinned, and I have acted perversely
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing and are combined for emphasis. AT: "I have sinned terribly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: But these sheep, what have they done?
tn.text: David uses a question and compares the people to sheep to emphasize that they have done nothing wrong. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "These ordinary people have done nothing wrong." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Please let your hand punish me
tn.text: Here the metonym "hand" refers to power. AT: "Please punish me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: bowed to the king with his face to the ground
tn.text: He was showing deep respect and honor to the king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: so that the plague may be removed from the people
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that Yahweh will remove this plague from the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Do with it what is good in your sight
tn.text: The phrase "in your sight" represents the opinion or idea of David. AT: "Do with it what you think is good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
heavy boards used to separate grain from the rest of the wheat plant

tn.ref: I will not offer ... anything that costs me nothing
tn.text: This can be stated in a positive form. AT: "I will only offer ... something that I have paid for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"50 shekels." A shekel is 11 grams. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
Here the metonym "land" stands for the people of Israel. AT: "on behalf of the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: caused the plague to be contained"
tn.text: "caused the plague to end"
